There are now two predictors, and they are both statistically significant in predicting win percent. You are adding one more degree of freedom to the model, taking that away from the error. By doing so, you create less room for error to occur within your model. The more you add explanatory variables, the more unexplained variation, or error, is accounted for because you are splitting up the work by each variable. However, the more you increase the degrees of freedom, the less meaningful each explanatory factor becomes, because each variable explains a smaller sub-section of the error.

It should have a lower SS error because it should have less residuals leftover. This is because adding another explanatory variable should be able to explain more variation and, thus, should, also leave less residual/error since the data should be more accurate.
Because the new model is explaining more variation. Therefore, more error is being explained and transferred to the Model SS.
The SS error would probably be lower because the more values there are, the bigger chance there is for values to be closer to the true mean which would decrease error.

SS Error is made up of SSTotal (which is empty model) - SS Error(from the model). I think that it would have a lower SS error simply because it has two predictors instead of one. In this class, we learned that the more predictors, the more variation that model will be able to explain.

Because we are adding two explanatory variables, so a greater share of the variation left unexplained from the empty model will be explained by the two-predictor model. SS Total will remain the same since it's based on the empty model, but the new complex model will explain more of the SS Total, so SS Model will increase, and therefore SS Error, the share of SS Total left unexplained by the new complex model, will decrease. SS Total is the sum of SS Model and SS Error, so when variation is explained and SS Model increases, SS Error has to decrease.

I think this is true because the two-predictor model explains more variation in the outcome variable than with just one predictor, so the SS model will be higher, and thus the SS error lower. SS total remains the same.
